turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Seigneurial system of New France.
turn.1: What were the duties of the Seigneurial system of New France?
turn.2: This stipulated that they were obliged to improve their landholdings or these would be confiscated.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: By ordinance of the Intendant in 1682, a socager could not hold more than two villeinages.
turn.5: What happened to those who did not hold land?
turn.6: The lord of the manor rented most of the land to tenants, known as "censitaires" or "habitants", who cleared the land, built houses and other buildings, and farmed the land.
turn.7: What were the different classes of people and their roles in the Seigneurial system?
turn.8: A smaller portion of the land was kept as a demesne (land owned by the manorial lord and farmed by his family or by hired labour) which was economically significant in the early days of settlement, though less thereafter.
turn.9: What is the most interesting part of the article, to you?
turn.10: Manorial land tenure in New France differed somewhat from its counterpart in France; the manorial lords of New France were not always nobles, though many were.
turn.12: Fiefs in North America were granted to military officers and – as in France – many were owned by the Catholic clergy.
